verses.text: After having said, "fellow-prisoner"; in order that he may not therewith depress the soul of his hearers, see how by this expression he rouseth them up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:81
verses.text: "Fellow-workers," he saith, "unto the kingdom of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:82
verses.text: So that being partakers of the trials, they become partakers of the kingdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:83
verses.text: "Who have been a comfort to me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:84
verses.text: He shows them to be great persons, seeing that to Paul they have been a comfort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:85
verses.text: But let us see the wisdom of Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:86
verses.text: "Walk in wisdom," he saith, "towards them that are without, redeeming the time".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:87
verses.text: (Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:88
verses.text: ) That is, the time is not yours, but theirs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:89
verses.text: Do not then wish to have your own way, but redeem the time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:90
verses.text: And he said not simply, "Buy," but "redeem," making it yours after another manner.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:91
verses.text: For it were the part of excessive madness, to invent occasions of war and enmity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:92
verses.text: For over and above the undergoing of superfluous and profitless dangers, there is this additional harm, that the Greeks will not come over to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:93
verses.text: For when thou art amongst the brethren, reason is thou shouldest be bold; but when without, thou oughtest not to be so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:94
verses.text: Seest thou how everywhere he speaks of those without, the Greeks? Wherefore also when writing to Timothy, he said, "Moreover, he must have good testimony from them that are without".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:95
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:96
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:97
verses.text: ) And again, "For what have I to do with judging them that are without".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:98
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:99
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:100
verses.text: ) "Walk in wisdom," he saith, "toward them that are without".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:101
verses.text: For "without," they are, even though they live in the same world with us, seeing they are without the kingdom, and the paternal mansion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:102
verses.text: And he comforts them withal, by calling the others "without," as he said above, "Your life is hid with Christ in God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:103
verses.text: (Col.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:104
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:105
verses.text: )  Then, he saith, seek ye glory, then honors, then all those other things, but not so now, but give them up to those without.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:106
verses.text: Next, lest thou think that he is speaking of money, he adds, "Let your speech be always with grace, seasoned with salt, that ye may know how ye ought to answer each one".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:107
verses.text: That it may not be full of hypocrisy, for this is not "grace," nor "a seasoning with salt".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:108
verses.text: For instance, if it be needful to pay court to any one without incurring danger, refuse not to do so; if the occasion require that thou discourse civilly, think not the doing so flattery, do everything that pertaineth to honor, so that piety be not injured.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:109
verses.text: Seest thou not how Daniel payeth court to an impious man? Seest thou not the three children, how wisely they bore themselves, showing both courage, and boldness in speaking, and yet nothing rash nor galling, for so it had not been boldness, but vainglory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:110
verses.text: "That ye may know," he saith, "how ye ought to answer every man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:111
verses.text: For the ruler ought to be answered in one way, the ruled in another, the rich in one way, the poor in another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:112
verses.text: Wherefore? Because the souls of those who are rich, and in authority, are weaker, more inflammable, more fluctuating, so that towards them, one should use condescension; those of the poor, and the ruled, firmer and more intelligent, so that to these one should use greater boldness of speech; looking to one thing, their edification.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:113
verses.text: Not that because one is rich, another poor, the former is to be honored more, the latter less, but because of his weakness, let the former be supported, the latter not so: for instance, when there is no cause for it, do not call the Greek "polluted," nor be insulting; but if thou be asked concerning his doctrine, answer that it is polluted, and impious; but when none asketh thee, nor forceth thee to speak, it becomes thee not causelessly to challenge to thee his enmity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:114
verses.text: For what need is there to prepare for thyself gratuitous hostilities? Again, if thou art instructing any one; speak on the subject at present before thee, otherwise be silent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:115
verses.text: If the speech be "seasoned with salt," should it fall into a soul that is of loose texture, it will brace up its slackness; into one that is harsh, it will smooth its ruggedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:116
verses.text: Let it be gracious, and so neither hard, nor yet weak, but let it have both sternness and pleasantness therewith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:117
verses.text: For if one be immoderately stern, he doth more harm than good; and if he be immoderately complaisant, he giveth more pain than pleasure, so that everywhere there ought to be moderation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:118
verses.text: Be not downcast, and sour visaged, for this is offensive; nor yet be wholly relaxed, for this is open to contempt and treading under foot; but, like the bee, culling the virtue of each, of the one its cheerfulness, of the other its gravity, keep clear of the fault.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:119
verses.text: For if a physician dealeth not with all bodies alike, much more ought not a teacher.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:120
verses.text: And yet better will the body bear unsuitable medicines, than the soul language; for instance, a Greek cometh to thee, and becomes thy friend; discourse not at all with him on this subject, until he have become a close friend, and after he hath become so, do it gradually.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:121
verses.text: See, when Paul also had come to Athens, how he discoursed with them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:122
verses.text: He said not, "O polluted, and all-polluted"; but what? "Ye men of Athens, in all things I perceive that ye are somewhat superstitious".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:123
verses.text: (Acts xvii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:124
verses.text: ) Again, when to insult was needful, he refused not; but with great vehemency he said to Elymas, "O full of all guile and all villainy, son of the devil, enemy of all righteousness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:125
verses.text: For as to have insulted those had been senselessness, so not to have insulted this one had been softness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:126
verses.text: Again, art thou brought unto a ruler on a matter of business, see that thou render him the honors that are his due.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:127
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:128
verses.text: "They shall make known unto you," he saith, "all things that are done here".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:129
verses.text: Why didst thou not come with them, says one? But what is, "They shall make known unto you all things"? My bonds, that is, and all the other things that detain me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:130
verses.text: I then, who pray to see them, who also send others, should not myself have remained behind, had not some great necessity detained me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:131
verses.text: And yet this is not the language of accusations—yes, of vehement accusation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:132
verses.text: For the assuring them that he had both fallen into trials, and was bearing them nobly, is the part of one who was confirming the fact, and lifting up again their souls.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:133
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:134
verses.text: "With Onesimus," he saith, "the beloved, and faithful brother".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:135
verses.text: Paul calleth a slave, brother: with reason; seeing that he styleth himself the servant of the faithful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:136
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:137
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:138
verses.text: ) Bring we down all of us our pride, tread we under foot our boastfulness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:139
verses.text: Paul nameth himself a slave, he that is worth the world, and ten thousands of heavens; and dost thou entertain high thoughts? He that seizeth all things for spoil as he will, he that hath the first place in the kingdom of heaven, he that was crowned, he that ascended into the third heaven, calleth servants, "brethren," and "fellow-servants".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:140
verses.text: Where is your madness? where is your arrogance?  So trustworthy was Onesimus become, as to be entrusted even with such things as these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:141
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:142
verses.text: "And Mark," he saith, "the cousin of Barnabas, touching whom ye received commandments, receive him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:143
verses.text: Perhaps they had received commandments from Barnabas.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:144
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:145
verses.text: "Who are of the circumcision".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:146
verses.text: He represseth the swelling pride of the Jews, and inspiriteth the souls of these, the Colossians, because few of them were of the circumcision, the greater number of the Gentiles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:147
verses.text: "Men that have been," he saith, "a comfort unto me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:148
verses.text: He shows himself to be set in the midst of great trials.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:149
verses.text: So that neither is this a small thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:150
verses.text: When we comfort the Saints by presence, by words, by assiduous attendance, when we suffer adversity together with them, (for he saith, "as bound with those in bonds"; Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:151
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:152
verses.text: ) when we make their sufferings ours, we shall also be partakers in their crowns.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:153
verses.text: Hast thou not been dragged to the stadium? Hast thou not entered into the lists? It is another that strips himself, another that wrestles; but if thou be so minded, thou too shall be a sharer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:154
verses.text: Anoint him, become his favorer and partisan, from without the lists shout loudly for him, stir up his strength, refresh his spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:155
verses.text: It follows that the same things should be done in all other cases.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:156
verses.text: For Paul stood not in need, but in order to stimulate them he said these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:157
verses.text: Thou therefore in the case of all others, stop the mouths of those who would abuse such an one, procure favorers for him, receive him as he cometh forth with great attention, so shalt thou be a sharer in his crowns, so, in his glory; and if thou do no other thing, but only hast pleasure in what is done, even thus thou sharest in no common degree, for thou hast contributed love, the sum of all good things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:158
verses.text: For if they that weep seem to share in the grief of those in sorrow, and gratify them mightily, and remove the excess of their woe, much more do they also that rejoice with others, make their pleasure greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:159
verses.text: For how great an evil it is not to have companions in sorrow, hear the Prophet saying, "And I looked for one to lament with me, but there was none".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:160
verses.text: Wherefore Paul also saith, "Rejoice with them that rejoice; and weep with them that weep".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:161
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:162
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:163
verses.text: ) Increase their pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:164
verses.text: If thou see thy brother in good esteem, say not, "the esteem is his, why should I rejoice".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:165
verses.text: These words are not those of a brother, but of an enemy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:166
verses.text: If thou be so minded, it is not his, but thine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:167
verses.text: Thou hast the power of making it greater, if thou be not downcast, but pleased, if thou be cheerful, if joyous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:168
verses.text: And that it is so, is evident from this; the envious envy not those only who are in good esteem, but those as well who rejoice at their good esteem, so conscious are they that these also are interested in that good esteem; and these are they who do glory most in it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:169
verses.text: For the other even blushes when praised exceedingly; but these with great pleasure pride themselves upon it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:170
verses.text: See ye not in the case of athletes, how the one is crowned, the other is not crowned; but the grief and the joy is amongst the favorers and disfavorers, these are they that leap, they that caper?  See how great a thing is the not envying.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:171
verses.text: The toil is another's, the pleasure is thine; another wears the crown, and thou caperest, thou art gay.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:172
verses.text: For tell me, seeing it is another that hath conquered, why dost thou leap? But they also know well, that what hath been done is common.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:173
verses.text: Therefore they do not accuse this man indeed, but they try to beat down the victory; and you hear them saying such words as these, "(There) I expunged thee," and, "I beat thee down".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:174
verses.text: Although the deed was another's, still the praise is thine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:175
verses.text: But if in things without, not to envy, but to make another's good one's own, is so great a good, much more in the victory of the devil over us he breathes the more furiously, evidently because we are more pleased.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:176
verses.text: Wicked though he is, and bitter, he well knows that this pleasure is great.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:177
verses.text: Wouldest thou pain him? Be glad and rejoice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:178
verses.text: Wouldest thou gladden him? Be sad-visaged.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:179
verses.text: The pain he has from thy brother's victory, thou soothest by thy sadness; thou standest with him, severed from thy brother, thou workest greater mischief than he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:180
verses.text: For it is not the same for one that is an enemy to do the deeds of an enemy, and for a friend to stand with an enemy; such an one is more detestable than an enemy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:181
verses.text: If thy brother have gained good reputation either by speaking, or by brilliant or successful achievement, become thou a sharer in his reputation, show that he is a member of thine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:182
verses.text: "And how?" saith one, "for the reputation is not mine".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:183
verses.text: Never speak so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:184
verses.text: Compress thy lips.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:185
verses.text: If thou hadst been near me, thou that speakest on that wise, I would have even put my hand over thy lips: lest the enemy should hear thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:186
verses.text: Oftentimes we have enmities with one another, and we discover them not to our enemies; dost thou then discover thine to the devil? Say not so, think not so; but the very reverse: "he is one of my members, the glory passes on to the body".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:187
verses.text: "How then is it," saith one, "that those without are not so minded?" Because of thy fault: when they see thee counting his pleasure not thine own, they too count it not thine: were they to see thee appropriating it, they durst not do so, but thou wouldest become equally illustrious with him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:188
verses.text: Thou hast not gained reputation by speaking; but by sharing in his joy thou hast gained more renown than he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:189
verses.text: For if love be a great thing, and the sum of all, thou hast received the crown this gives; he, that for oratory, thou, that for exceeding love; he displayed force of words, but thou by deeds hast cast down envy, hast trodden under foot the evil eye.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:190
verses.text: So that in reason thou oughtest rather to be crowned than he, thy contest is the more brilliant; thou hast not only trodden under foot envy, but thou hast even done somewhat else.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:191
verses.text: He hath one crown only, but thou two, and those both brighter than his one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:192
verses.text: What are these? One, that which thou wonnest against envy, another, which thou art encircled with by love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:193
verses.text: For the sharing in his joy is a proof not only of thy being free from envy, but also of being rooted in love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:194
verses.text: Him ofttimes some human passion sorely disquieteth, vainglory for instance; but thou art free from every passion, for it is not of vainglory that thou rejoicest at another's good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:195
verses.text: Hath he righted up the Church, tell me? hath he increased the congregation? Praise him; again thou hast a twofold crown; thou hast struck down envy; thou hast enwreathed thee with love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:196
verses.text: Yea, I implore and beseech thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:197
verses.text: Wilt thou hear of a third crown even? Him, men below applaud, thee, the Angels above.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:198
verses.text: For it is not the same thing, to make a display of eloquence, and to rule the passions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:199
verses.text: This praise is for a season, that for ever; this, of men, that, of God; this man is crowned openly; but thou art crowned in secret, where thy Father seeth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:200
verses.text: If it were possible to have peeled off the body and seen the soul of each, I would have shown thee that this is more dignified than the other, more resplendent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:201
verses.text: Tread we under foot the goads of envy, we advantage ourselves, beloved, ourselves shall we enwreath with the crown.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:202
verses.text: He that envieth another fighteth with God, not with him; for when he seeth him to have grace, and is grieved, and wisheth the Church pulled down, he fighteth not with him, but with God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:203
verses.text: For tell me, if one should adorn a king's daughter, and by his adorning and gracing her, gain for himself renown; and another person should wish her to be ill attired, and him to be unable to adorn her; against whom would he have been plotting mischief? Against the other? or against her and her father? So too now, thou that enviest, fightest with the Church, thou warrest with God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:204
verses.text: For, since with the good repute of thy brother is interwoven also the Church's profit, need is, that if the one be undone, the other shall be undone also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:205
verses.text: So that, in this regard also, thou doest a deed of Satan, seeing thou plottest mischief against the body of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:206
verses.text: Art thou pained at this man? Wrongly, when he hath in nothing wronged thee; yea, much rather, thou art pained at Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:207
verses.text: Wherein hath He wronged thee, that thou wilt not suffer His body to be decked with beauty? that thou wilt not suffer His bride to be adorned? Consider, I pray thee, the punishment, how sore.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:208
verses.text: Thou gladdenest thine enemies; and him too himself, the man in good esteem, whom through thy envy thou wishest to grieve, thou dost the rather gladden; thou dost by thine envy the rather show that he is in good esteem, for otherwise thou wouldest not have envied him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:209
verses.text: Thou showest the rather that thou art in punishment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:210
verses.text: I am ashamed indeed to exhort you from such motives, but seeing our weakness is so great, let us be instructed even from these, and free ourselves from this destructive passion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:211
verses.text: Grievest thou that he is in good esteem? then why swellest thou that esteem by envying? Wishest thou to punish him? Why then showest thou that thou art pained? Why punish thyself before him, whom thou wouldest not have well esteemed? Thereafter double will be his pleasure, and thy punishment; not only because thou provest him to be great; but because thou begettest in him yet another pleasure, by punishing thyself; and again, at what thou art pained, he is pleased, whilst thou enviest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:212
verses.text: See how we deal ourselves heavy blows without perceiving it! He is an enemy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:213
verses.text: And yet, why an enemy? What wrong hath he done? Still, however, by this we make our enemy the more illustrious, and thereby punish ourselves the more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:214
verses.text: And herein again we punish ourselves, if we have discovered that he knows it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:215
verses.text: For perhaps he is not pleased, but we thinking him to be so, are again pained on that account.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:216
verses.text: Cease then your envying.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:217
verses.text: Why inflictest thou wounds upon thyself?  Think we of these things, beloved; of those two crowns for them that envy not; of those praises from men, of those from God; of the evils that come of envying; and so shall we be able to quell the brute, and to be in good esteem before God, and to obtain the same things with those who are of good esteem.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 12:218
verses.text: For perhaps we shall obtain them, and if we obtain them not, it will be for our advantage; still, even so, we shall be able, if we have lived to the glory of God, to obtain the good things promised to them that love Him, through the grace and love toward man of our Lord Jesus Christ, with whom, &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:1
verses.text: Homily XII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:2
verses.text: Colossians iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:3
verses.text: ,  "Epaphras, who is one of you, a servant of Christ Jesus, saluteth you, always striving for you in his prayers, that ye may stand perfect and fully assured in all the will of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:4
verses.text: For I bear him witness, that he hath much zeal for you, and for them in Laodicea, and for them in Hierapolis".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:5
verses.text: In the commencement of this Epistle also, he commended this man for his love; for even to praise is a sign of love; thus in the beginning he said, "Who also declared unto us your love in the Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:6
verses.text: (Col.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:7
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:8
verses.text: ) To pray for one is also a sign of love, and causeth love again.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:9
verses.text: He commends him moreover in order to open a door to his teachings, for reverendness in the teacher is the disciples' advantage; and so again is his saying, "one of you," in order that they might pride themselves upon the man, as producing such men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:10
verses.text: And he saith, "always striving for you in prayers".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:11
verses.text: He said not simply "praying," but "striving," trembling and fearing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:12
verses.text: "For I bear him witness," he saith, "that he hath much zeal for you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:13
verses.text: A trustworthy witness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:14
verses.text: "That he hath," he saith, "much zeal for you," that is, that he loveth you exceedingly; and burneth with passionate affection for you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:15
verses.text: "And them in Laodicea, and them in Hierapolis".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:16
verses.text: He commendeth him to those also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:17
verses.text: But whence were they to know this? They would assuredly have heard; however, they would also learn it when the Epistle was read.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:18
verses.text: For he said, "Cause that it be read also in the church of the Laodiceans".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:19
verses.text: "That ye may stand perfect," he saith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:20
verses.text: At once he both accuseth them, and without offensiveness gives them advice and counsel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:21
verses.text: For it is possible both to be perfect, and withal not to stand, as if one were to know all, and still be wavering; it is possible also not to be perfect, and yet to stand, as if one were to know a part, and stand not firmly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:22
verses.text: But this man prayeth for both: "That ye may stand perfect," he saith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:23
verses.text: See how again he has reminded them of what he said about the Angels, and about life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:24
verses.text: "And fully assured," he saith, "in all the will of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:25
verses.text: It is not enough, simply to do His will.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:26
verses.text: He that is "filled," suffereth not any other will to be within him, for if so, he is not wholly filled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:27
verses.text: "For I bear him witness," he saith, "that he hath much zeal".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:28
verses.text: Both "zeal," and "great"; both are intensitive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:29
verses.text: As he saith himself, when writing to the Corinthians, "For I am jealous over you with a godly jealousy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:30
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:31
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:32
verses.text: )  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:33
verses.text: "Luke, the beloved physician, saluteth you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:34
verses.text: This is the Evangelist.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:35
verses.text: It is not to lower this man that he placeth him after, but to raise the other, viz.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:36
verses.text: Epaphroditus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:37
verses.text: It is probable that there were others called by this name.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:38
verses.text: "And Demas," he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:39
verses.text: After saying, "Luke, the physician, saluteth you," he added, "the beloved".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:40
verses.text: And no small praise is this, but even great exceedingly, to be beloved of Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:41
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:42
verses.text: "Salute the brethren that are in Laodicea, and Nymphas, and the Church that is in their house".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:43
verses.text: See how he cements, and knits them together with one another, not by salutation only, but also by interchanging his Epistles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:44
verses.text: Then again he pays a compliment by addressing him individually.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:45
verses.text: And this he doth not without a reason, but in order to lead the others also to emulate his zeal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:46
verses.text: For it is not a small thing not to be numbered with the rest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:47
verses.text: Mark further how he shows the man to be great, seeing his house was a church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:48
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:49
verses.text: "And when this Epistle hath been read among you, cause that it be read also in the church of the Laodiceans".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:50
verses.text: I suppose there are some of the things therein written, which it was needful that those also should hear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:51
verses.text: And they would have the greater advantage of recognizing their own errors in the charges brought against others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:52
verses.text: "And that ye also read the Epistle from Laodicea".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:53
verses.text: Some say that this is not Paul's to them, but theirs to Paul, for he said not that to the Laodiceans, but that written "from Laodicea".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:54
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:55
verses.text: "And say to Archippus, Take heed to the ministry which thou hast received in the Lord, that thou fulfill it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:56
verses.text: Wherefore doth he not write to him? Perhaps he needed it not, but only a bare reminding, so as to be more diligent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:57
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:58
verses.text: "The salutation of me, Paul, with mine own hand".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:59
verses.text: This is a proof of their sincerity and affection; that they both looked at his handwriting, and that with emotion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:60
verses.text: "Remember my bonds".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:61
verses.text: Wonderful! How great the consolation! For this is enough to cheer them on to all things, and make them bear themselves more nobly in their trials; but he made them not only the braver, but also the more nearly interested.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:62
verses.text: "Grace be with you, Amen".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:63
verses.text: It is great praise, and greater than all the rest, his saying of Epaphras, "who is one of you, a servant of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:64
verses.text: And he calleth him a minister for them, like as he termeth himself also a minister of the Church, as when he saith, "Whereof I Paul was made a minister".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:65
verses.text: (Col.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:66
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:67
verses.text: ) To the same dignity he advances this man; and above he calleth him a "fellow-servant" (Col.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:68
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:69
verses.text: ), and here, "a servant".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:70
verses.text: "Who is of you," he saith, as if speaking to a mother, and saying, "who is of thy womb".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:71
verses.text: But this praise might have gendered envy; therefore he commendeth him not from these things only, but also from what had regard to themselves; and so he does away with envy, both in the former place, and here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:72
verses.text: "Always," he saith, "striving for you," not now only, whilst with us, to make a display; nor yet only whilst with you, to make a display before you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:73
verses.text: By saying, "striving," he hath showed his great earnestness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:74
verses.text: Then, that he might not seem to be flattering them, he added, "that he hath much zeal for you, and for them in Laodicea, and for them in Hierapolis".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:75
verses.text: And the words, "that ye may stand perfect," are not words of flattery, but of a reverend teacher.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:76
verses.text: Both "fully assured" he saith, "and perfect".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:77
verses.text: The one he granted them, the other he said was lacking.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:78
verses.text: And he said not, "that ye be not shaken," but, "that ye may stand".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:79
verses.text: Their being saluted, however, by many, is refreshing to them, seeing that not only their friends from among themselves; but others also, remember them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:80
verses.text: "And say to Archippus, Take heed to the ministry which thou hast received in the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:81
verses.text: His chief aim is to subject them to him entirely.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:82
verses.text: For they could no more have complaint against him for rebuking them, when they themselves had taken it all upon them; for it is not reasonable to talk to the disciples about the teacher.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:83
verses.text: But to stop their mouths, he writes thus to them; "Say to Archippus," he saith, "Take heed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:84
verses.text: This word is everywhere used to alarm; as when he saith, "Take heed of dogs".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:85
verses.text: (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:86
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:87
verses.text: ) "Take heed lest there shall be any one that maketh spoil of you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:88
verses.text: (Col.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:89
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:90
verses.text: ) "Take heed lest by any means this liberty of yours become a stumblingblock to the weak".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:91
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:92
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:93
verses.text: ) And he always so expresses himself when he would terrify.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:94
verses.text: "Take heed," he saith, "to the ministry which thou hast received in the Lord, that thou fulfill it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:95
verses.text: He doth not even allow him the power of choosing, as he saith himself, "For if I do this of mine own will, I have a reward: but if not of mine own will, I have a stewardship entrusted to me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:96
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:97
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:98
verses.text: ) "That thou fulfill it," continually using diligence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:99
verses.text: "Which thou hast received in the Lord, that thou fulfill it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:100
verses.text: Again, the word "in" means "through the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:101
verses.text: He gave it thee, says he, not we.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:102
verses.text: He subjects them also to him, when he shows that they had been committed to his hands by God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:103
verses.text: "Remember my bonds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:104
verses.text: Grace be with you, Amen".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:105
verses.text: He hath released their terror.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:106
verses.text: For although their teacher be in bonds, yet "grace" releaseth him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:107
verses.text: This too is of grace, the granting him to be put in bonds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:108
verses.text: For hear Luke saying, The Apostles returned "from the presence of the council, rejoicing that they were counted worthy to suffer dishonor for the Name".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:109
verses.text: (Acts v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:110
verses.text: ) For both to suffer shame, and to be put in bonds, is indeed to be "counted worthy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:111
verses.text: For, if he that hath one whom he loveth, deemeth it gain to suffer aught for his sake, much rather then is it so to suffer for the sake of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:112
verses.text: Repine we not then at our tribulations for Christ's sake, but let us also remember Paul's bonds, and be this our incitement.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:113
verses.text: For instance: dost thou exhort any to give to the poor for Christ's sake? Remind them of Paul's bonds, and bemoan thy misery and theirs, seeing that he indeed gave up even his body to bonds for His sake, but thou wilt not give a portion even of thy food.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:114
verses.text: Art thou lifted up because of thy good deeds? Remember Paul's bonds, that thou hast suffered nought of that kind, and thou wilt be lifted up no more.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:115
verses.text: Covetest thou any of the things that are thy neighbor's? Remember Paul's bonds, and thou wilt see how unreasonable it is, that whilst he was in perils, thou shouldest be in delights.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:116
verses.text: Again, is thine heart set upon self-indulgence? Picture to thy mind Paul's prison-house; thou art his disciple, his fellow-soldier.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:117
verses.text: How is it reasonable, that thy fellow-soldier should be in bonds, and thou in luxury? Art thou in affliction? Dost thou deem thyself forsaken? Hear Paul's bonds, and thou wilt see, that to be in affliction is no proof of being forsaken.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:118
verses.text: Wouldest thou wear silken robes? Remember Paul's bonds; and these things will appear to thee more worthless than the filth-bespattered rags of her that sitteth apart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:119
verses.text: Wouldest thou array thee with golden trinkets? Picture to thy mind Paul's bonds, and these things will seem to thee no better than a withered bulrush.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:120
verses.text: Wouldest thou tire thine hair, and be beautiful to see? Think of Paul's squalidness within that prison-house, and thou wilt burn for that beauty, and deem this the extreme of ugliness, and wilt groan bitterly through longing for those bonds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:121
verses.text: Wouldest thou daub thee with pastes and pigments, and such like things? Think of his tears: a three-years space, night and day, he ceased not to weep.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:122
verses.text: (Acts xx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:123
verses.text: ) With this adorning deck thy cheek; these tears do make it bright.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:124
verses.text: I say not, that thou weep for others, (I wish indeed it could be even so, but this is too high for thee,) but for thine own sins I advise thee to do this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:125
verses.text: Hast thou ordered thy slave to be put in bonds, and wast thou angry, and exasperated? Remember Paul's bonds, and thou wilt straightway stay thine anger; remember that we are of the bound, not the binders, of the bruised in heart, not the bruisers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:126
verses.text: Hast thou lost self-control, and shouted loud in laughter? Think of his lamentations, and thou wilt groan; such tears will show thee brighter far.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:127
verses.text: Seest thou any persons rioting and dancing? Remember his tears.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:128
verses.text: What fountain has gushed forth so great streams as those eyes did tears? "Remember my tears" (Acts xx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:129
verses.text: ), he saith, as here "bonds".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:130
verses.text: And with reason he spoke thus to them, when he sent for them from Ephesus to Miletus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:131
verses.text: For he was then speaking to teachers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:132
verses.text: He demands of those therefore, that they should sympathize also, but of these that they should only encounter dangers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:133
verses.text: What fountain wilt thou compare to these tears? That in Paradise, which watereth the whole earth? But thou wilt have mentioned nothing like it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:134
verses.text: For this fount of tears watered souls, not earth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:135
verses.text: If one were to show us Paul bathed in tears, and groaning, would not this be better far to see, than countless choirs gayly crowned? I am not now speaking of you; but, if one, having pulled away from the theater and the stage some wanton fellow, burning and drunken with carnal love, were to show him a young virgin in the very flower of her age, surpassing her fellows, both in other respects, and in her face more than the rest of her person, having an eye, tender and soft, that gently resteth, and gently rolleth, moist, mild, calmly smiling, and arrayed in much modesty and much grace, fringed with dark lashes both under and over, having an eyeball, so to speak, alive, a forehead radiant; underneath, again, a cheek shaded to exact redness, lying smooth as marble, and even; and then any one should show me Paul weeping; leaving that maiden, I would have eagerly sprung away to the sight of him; for from his eyes there beamed spiritual beauty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:136
verses.text: For that other transporteth the souls of youths, it scorcheth and inflameth them; but this, on the contrary, subdueth them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:137
verses.text: This maketh the eyes of the soul more beauteous, it curbeth the belly: it filleth with the love of wisdom, with much sympathy: and it is able to soften even a soul of adamant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:138
verses.text: With these tears the Church is watered, with these souls are planted; yea, though there be fire sensible and substantial, yet can these tears quench it; these tears quench the fiery darts of the wicked one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:139
verses.text: Remember we then these tears of his, and we shall laugh to scorn all present things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:140
verses.text: These tears did Christ pronounce blessed, saying, "Blessed are they that mourn, and blessed are they that weep, for they shall laugh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:141
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:142
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:143
verses.text: ; Luke vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:144
verses.text: ) Such tears did Isaiah too, and Jeremiah weep; and the former said, "Leave me alone, I will weep bitterly" (Isa.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:145
verses.text: xxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:146
verses.text: , Sept.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:147
verses.text: ): and the latter, "Who will give my head water, and mine eyes fountains of tears?" (Jer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:148
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:149
verses.text: ); as though the natural fount were not enough.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:150
verses.text: Nothing is sweeter than these tears; sweeter are they than any laughter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:151
verses.text: They that mourn, know how great consolation it possesseth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:152
verses.text: Let us not think this a thing to be deprecated, but one to be even exceedingly prayed for; not that others may sin, but that, when they sin, we may be heart-broken for them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:153
verses.text: Remember we these tears, these bonds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:154
verses.text: Surely too upon those bonds tears descended; but the death of the perishing, of those that had bound him in them, suffered him not to taste the pleasure of the bonds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:155
verses.text: For in their behalf he grieved, being a disciple of Him that bewept the priests of the Jews; not because they were going to crucify Him, but because they were themselves perishing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:156
verses.text: And He doeth not this Himself alone, but He thus exhorteth others also, saying, "Daughters of Jerusalem, weep not for Me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:157
verses.text: (Luke xxiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:158
verses.text: ) These eyes saw Paradise, saw the third heaven: but I count not them so blessed because of this sight, as because of those tears, through which they saw Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:159
verses.text: Blessed, indeed, was that sight; for he himself even glories in it, saying, "Have I not seen Jesus Christ our Lord?" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:160
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:161
verses.text: ); but more blessed so to weep.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:162
verses.text: In that sight many have been partakers, and those who have not so been, Christ the rather calls blessed, saying, "Blessed are they that have not seen, and yet have believed" (John xx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:163
verses.text: ); but unto this not many have attained.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:164
verses.text: For if to stay here for Christ's sake were more needful than to depart to Him (Philip.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:165
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:167
verses.text: ), for the sake of the salvation of others; surely then to groan for others' sakes, is more needful even than to see Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:168
verses.text: For if for His sake to be in hell, is rather to be desired, than to be with Him; and to be separated from Him for His sake more to be desired than to be with Him, (for this is what he said, "For I could wish that I myself were anathema from Christ" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:169
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:170
verses.text: ), much more is weeping for His sake.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:171
verses.text: "I ceased not," he saith, "to admonish everyone with tears".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:172
verses.text: (Acts xx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:173
verses.text: ) Wherefore? Not fearing the dangers; no; but as if one sitting by a sick man's side, and not knowing what would be the end, should weep for affection, fearing lest he should lose his life; so too did he; when he saw any one diseased, and could not prevail by rebuke, he thenceforward wept.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:174
verses.text: So did Christ also, that happily they might reverence His tears: thus, one sinned, He rebuked him; the rebuked spat upon Him, and sprang aloof; He wept, that haply He might win him even so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:175
verses.text: Remember we these tears: thus let us bring up our daughters, thus our sons; weeping when we see them in evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:176
verses.text: As many women as wish to be loved, let them remember Paul's tears, and groan: as many of you as are counted blest, as many as are in bridal chambers, as many as are in pleasure, remember these; as many as are in mourning, exchange tears for tears.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:177
verses.text: He mourned not for the dead; but for those that were perishing whilst alive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:178
verses.text: Shall I tell of other tears? Timothy also wept; for he was this man's disciple; wherefore also when writing to him he said, "Remembering thy tears, that I may be filled with joy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:179
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:180
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:181
verses.text: ) Many weep even from pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:182
verses.text: So it is also a matter of pleasure, and that of the utmost intensity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:183
verses.text: So the tears are not painful: yea, the tears that flow from such sorrow are even better far than those due to worldly pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:184
verses.text: Hear the Prophet saying, "The Lord hath heard the voice of my weeping, he hath heard the voice of my supplication".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:185
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:186
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:187
verses.text: ) For where is the tear not useful? in prayers? in exhortations? We get them an ill name, by using them not to what they are given us for.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:188
verses.text: When we entreat a sinning brother, we ought to weep, grieving and groaning; when we exhort any one, and he giveth us no heed, but goeth on perishing, we ought to weep.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:189
verses.text: These are the tears of heavenly wisdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:190
verses.text: When however one is in poverty, or bodily disease, or dead, not so; for these are not things worthy of tears.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:191
verses.text: As then we gain an ill name for laughter also, when we use it out of season; so too do we for tears, by having recourse to them unseasonably.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:192
verses.text: For the virtue of each thing then discovers itself when it is brought to its own fitting work, but when to one that is alien, it doth no longer so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:193
verses.text: For instance, wine is given for cheerfulness, not drunkenness, bread for nourishment, sexual intercourse for the procreation of children.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:194
verses.text: As then these things have gained an ill name, so also have tears.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:195
verses.text: Be there a law laid down, that they be used in prayers and exhortations only, and see how desirable a thing they will become.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:196
verses.text: Nothing doth so wipe out sins, as tears.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:197
verses.text: Tears show even this bodily countenance beautiful; for they win the spectator to pity, they make it respected in our eyes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:198
verses.text: Nothing is sweeter than tearful eyes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:199
verses.text: For this is the noblest member we have, and the most beautiful, and the soul's own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:200
verses.text: And therefore we are so bowed therewith, as though we saw the soul itself lamenting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:201
verses.text: I have not spoken these things without a reason; but in order that ye may cease your attendance at weddings, at dancings, at Satanical performances.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:202
verses.text: For see what the devil hath invented.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:203
verses.text: Since nature itself hath withheld women from the stage, and the disgraceful things enacted there, he hath introduced into the women's apartment the furniture of the theater, I mean, wanton men and harlots.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:204
verses.text: This pestilence the custom of marriages hath introduced, or rather, not of marriages, far be it, but of our own silliness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:205
verses.text: What is it thou doest, O man? Dost thou not know what thou art at? Thou marriest a wife for chastity, and procreation of children; what then mean these harlots? That there may be, one answereth, greater gladness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:206
verses.text: And yet is not this rather madness? Thou insultest thy bride, thou insultest the women that are invited.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:207
verses.text: For if they are delighted with such proceedings, the thing is an insult.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:208
verses.text: If to see harlots acting indecorously conferreth any honor, wherefore dost thou not drag thy bride also thither, that she too may see? It is quite indecent and disgraceful to introduce into one's house lewd fellows and dancers, and all that Satanic pomp.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:209
verses.text: "Remember," he saith, "my bonds".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:210
verses.text: Marriage is a bond, a bond ordained of God, a harlot is a severing and a dissolving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:211
verses.text: It is permitted you to embellish marriage with other things, such as full tables, and apparel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:212
verses.text: I do not cut off these things, lest I should seem to be clownish to an extreme; and yet Rebecca was content with her veil only (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:213
verses.text: xxiv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:214
verses.text: ); still I do not cut them off.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:215
verses.text: It is permitted you to embellish and set off marriage with apparel, with the presence of reverend men and reverend women.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:216
verses.text: Why introducest thou those mockeries? why those monsters? Tell us what it is thou hearest from them? What? dost thou blush to tell? Dost thou blush, and yet force them to do it? If it is honorable, wherefore dost thou not do it thyself as well? but if disgraceful, wherefore dost thou compel another? Everything should be full of chasteness, of gravity, of orderliness; but I see the reverse, people frisking like camels and mules.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:217
verses.text: For the virgin, her chamber is the only befitting place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:218
verses.text: "But," saith one, "she is poor".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:219
verses.text: Because she is poor, she ought to be modest also; let her have her character in the place of a fortune.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:220
verses.text: Has she no dowry to give with herself? Then why dost thou make her otherwise contemptible through her life and manners? I praise the custom, that virgins attend to do honor to their fellow; matrons attend to do honor to her who is made one of their order.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:221
verses.text: Rightly hath this been ordered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:222
verses.text: For these are two companies, one of virgins, the other of the married; the one are giving her up, the other receiving her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:223
verses.text: The bride is between them, neither virgin, nor wife, for she is coming forth from those, and entering into the fellowship of these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:224
verses.text: But those harlots, what mean they? They ought to hide their faces when marriage is celebrated; they ought to be dug into the earth, (for harlotry is the corruption of marriage,) but we introduce them at our marriages.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:225
verses.text: And, when ye are engaged in any work, ye count it ill-omened to speak even a syllable of what is adverse to it; for instance, when thou sowest, when thou drawest off the wine from thy vats, thou wouldest not, even if asked, utter a syllable about vinegar; but here, where the object is chasteness, introduce ye the vinegar? for such is an harlot.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:226
verses.text: When ye are preparing sweet ointment, ye suffer nought ill-scented to be near.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:227
verses.text: Marriage is a sweet ointment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:228
verses.text: Why then introducest thou the foul stench of the dunghill into the preparation of thy ointment? What sayest thou? Shall the virgin dance, and yet feel no shame before her fellow? For she ought to have more gravity than the other; she hath at least come forth from the nurse's arm, and not from the palaestra.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:229
verses.text: For the virgin ought not to appear publicly at all at a marriage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:230
verses.text: Seest thou not how in kings' houses, the honored are within, about the king, the unhonored without? Do thou too be within about the bride.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:231
verses.text: But remain in the house in chasteness, expose not thy virginity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:232
verses.text: Either company is standing by, the one to show of what sort she is whom they are giving up, the other in order that they may guard her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:233
verses.text: Why disgracest thou the virgin estate? For if thou art such as this, the same will the bridegroom suspect her to be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:234
verses.text: If thou wishest to have men in love with thee, this is the part of saleswomen, green-grocers, and handicrafts-people.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:235
verses.text: Is not this a shame? To act unseemly is a shame even though it be a king's daughter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:236
verses.text: For doth her poverty stand in the way? or her course of life? Even if a virgin be a slave, let her abide in modesty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:237
verses.text: "For in Christ Jesus there can be neither bond nor free".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:238
verses.text: (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:239
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:240
verses.text: )  What? is marriage a theater? It is a mystery and a type of a mighty thing; and even if thou reverence not it, reverence that whose type it is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:241
verses.text: "This mystery," saith he, "is great, but I speak in regard of Christ and of the Church".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:242
verses.text: (Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:243
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:244
verses.text: ) It is a type of the Church, and of Christ, and dost thou introduce harlots at it? If then, saith one, neither virgins dance, nor the married, who is to dance? No one, for what need is there of dancing? In the Grecian mysteries there are dancings, but in ours, silence and decency, modesty, and bashfulness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:245
verses.text: A great mystery is being celebrated: forth with the harlots! forth with the profane! How is it a mystery? They come together, and the two make one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:246
verses.text: Wherefore is it that at his entrance indeed, there was no dancing, no cymbals, but great silence, great stillness; but when they come together, making not a lifeless image, nor yet the image of anything upon earth, but of God Himself, and after his likeness, thou introducest so great an uproar, and disturbest those that are there, and puttest the soul to shame, and confoundest it? They come, about to be made one body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:247
verses.text: See again a mystery of love! If the two become not one, so long as they continue two, they make not many, but when they are come into oneness, they then make many.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:248
verses.text: What do we learn from this? That great is the power of union.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:249
verses.text: The wise counsel of God at the beginning divided the one into two; and being desirous of showing that even after division it remaineth still one, He suffered not that the one should be of itself enough for procreation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:250
verses.text: For he is not one who is not yet united, but the half of one; and it is evident from this, that he begetteth no offspring, as was the case also beforetime.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:251
verses.text: Seest thou the mystery of marriage? He made of one, one; and again, having made these two, one, He so maketh one, so that now also man is produced of one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:252
verses.text: For man and wife are not two men, but one Man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:253
verses.text: And this may be confirmed from many sources; for instance, from James, from Mary the Mother of Christ, from the words, "He made them male and female".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:254
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:255
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:256
verses.text: ) If he be the head, and she the body, how are they two? Therefore the one holdeth the rank of a disciple, the other of a teacher, the one of a ruler, the other of a subject.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:257
verses.text: Moreover, from the very fashioning of her body, one may see that they are one, for she was made from his side, and they are, as it were, two halves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:258
verses.text: For this cause He also calleth her a help, to show that they are one (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:259
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:260
verses.text: ); for this cause He honoreth their cohabitation beyond both father and mother, to show that they are one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:261
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:262
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:263
verses.text: ) And in like manner a father rejoiceth both when son and daughter marry, as though the body were hastening to join a member of its own; and though so great a charge and expenditure of money is incurred still he cannot bear with indifference to see her unmarried.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:264
verses.text: For as though her own flesh itself were severed from her, each one separately is imperfect for the procreation of children, each one is imperfect as regards the constitution of this present life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:265
verses.text: Wherefore also the Prophet saith, "the residue of thy spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:266
verses.text: (Mal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:267
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:268
verses.text: , Sept.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:269
verses.text: ) And how become they one flesh? As if thou shouldest take away the purest part of gold, and mingle it with other gold; so in truth here also the woman as it were receiving the richest part fused by pleasure, nourisheth it and cherisheth it, and withal contributing her own share, restoreth it back a Man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:270
verses.text: And the child is a sort of bridge, so that the three become one flesh, the child connecting, on either side, each to other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:271
verses.text: For like as two cities, which a river divides throughout, become one, if a bridge connect them on both sides, so is it in this case; and yet more, when the very bridge in this case is formed of the substance of each.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:272
verses.text: As the body and the head are one body; for they are divided by the neck; but not divided more than connected, for it, lying between them brings together each with the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:273
verses.text: And it is the same as if a chorus that had been severed should, by taking one part of itself from this quarter, and the other again from the right, make one; or as these when come into close rank, and extending hands, become one; for the hands extended admit not of their being two.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:274
verses.text: Therefore to wit He said with accuracy of expression, not "they shall be one flesh" but joined together "into one flesh" (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:275
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:276
verses.text: , Sept.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:277
verses.text: ), namely, that of the child.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:278
verses.text: What then? when there is no child, will they not be two? Nay, for their coming together hath this effect, it diffuses and commingles the bodies of both.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:279
verses.text: And as one who hath cast ointment into oil, hath made the whole one; so in truth is it also here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:280
verses.text: I know that many are ashamed at what is said, and the cause of this is what I spoke of, your own lasciviousness, and unchasteness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:281
verses.text: The fact of marriages being thus performed, thus depraved, hath gained the thing an ill name: for "marriage is honorable, and the bed undefiled".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:282
verses.text: (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:283
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:284
verses.text: ) Why art thou ashamed of the honorable, why blushest thou at the undefiled? This is for heretics, this is for such as introduce harlots thither.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:285
verses.text: For this cause I am desirous of having it thoroughly purified, so as to bring it back again to its proper nobleness, so as to stop the mouths of the heretics.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:286
verses.text: The gift of God is insulted, the root of our generation; for about that root there is much dung and filth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:287
verses.text: This then let us cleanse away by our discourse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:288
verses.text: Endure then a little while, for he that holdeth filth must endure the stench.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:289
verses.text: I wish to show you that ye ought not to be ashamed at these things, but at those which ye do; but thou, passing by all shame at those, art ashamed at these; surely then thou condemnest God who hath thus decreed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:290
verses.text: Shall I tell how marriage is also a mystery of the Church? As Christ came into the Church, and she was made of him, and he united with her in a spiritual intercourse, "for," saith one, "I have espoused you to one husband, a pure virgin".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:291
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:292
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:293
verses.text: ) And that we are of Him, he saith, of His members, "and of His flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:294
verses.text: Thinking then on all these things, let us not cast shame upon so great a mystery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:295
verses.text: Marriage is a type of the presence of Christ, and art thou drunken at it? Tell me; if thou sawest an image of the king, wouldest thou dishonor it? By no means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:296
verses.text: Now the practices at marriages seem to be a matter of indifference, but they are the causes of great mischiefs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:297
verses.text: All is full of lawlessness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:298
verses.text: "Filthiness, and foolish talking, and jesting, let it not proceed," saith he, "out of your mouth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:299
verses.text: (Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:300
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:301
verses.text: ; iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:302
verses.text: ) Now all these things are filthiness, foolish talking, and jesting; and not these simply, but with aggravation, for the thing has become an art, and there are great praises for those that pursue it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:303
verses.text: Sins have become an art! We pursue them not in any chance way, but with earnestness, with science, and thenceforth the devil takes the command of his own array.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:304
verses.text: For where drunkenness is, there is unchasteness: where filthy talking, there the devil is at hand bringing in his own contributions; with such an entertainment, tell me, dost thou celebrate the mystery of Christ? and invitest thou the devil?  I dare say you consider me offensive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:305
verses.text: For this too is a property of extreme pervertedness, that even one that rebuketh you incurs your ridicule as one that is austere.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:306
verses.text: Hear ye not Paul, saying, "Whatsoever ye do, whether ye eat or drink or whatsoever ye do, do all to the glory of God"? ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:307
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:308
verses.text: ) But ye do all to ill report and dishonor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:309
verses.text: Hear ye not the Prophet, saying, "Serve the Lord with fear, and rejoice unto Him with trembling?" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:310
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:311
verses.text: ) But ye are wholly without restraint.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:312
verses.text: Is it not possible both to enjoy pleasure, and to do so with safety? Art thou desirous of hearing beautiful songs? Best of all indeed, thou oughtest not; nevertheless, I condescend if thou wilt have it so: do not hear those Satanic ones, but the spiritual.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:313
verses.text: Art thou desirous of seeing choirs of dancers? Behold the choir of Angels.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:314
verses.text: And how is it possible, saith one, to see them? If thou drive away all these things, even Christ will come to such a marriage, and Christ being present, the choir of Angels is present also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:315
verses.text: If thou wilt, He will even now work miracles as He did then; He will make even now the water, wine (John ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:316
verses.text: ); and what is much more wonderful, He will convert this unstable and dissolving pleasure, this cold desire, and change it into the spiritual.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:317
verses.text: This is to make of water, wine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:318
verses.text: Where pipers are, by no means there is Christ; but even if He should have entered, He first casts these forth, and then He works His wonders.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:319
verses.text: What can be more disagreeable than this Satanic pomp? where everything is inarticulate, everything without significancy; and if there be anything articulate, again all is shameful, all is noisome.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:320
verses.text: Nothing is more pleasurable than virtue, nothing sweeter than orderliness, nothing more amiable than gravity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:321
verses.text: Let any celebrate such a marriage as I speak of; and he shall find the pleasure; but what sort of marriages these are, take heed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:322
verses.text: First seek a husband for the virgin, who will be truly a husband, and a protector; as though thou wert intending to place a head upon a body; as though about to give not a slave, but a daughter into his hands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:323
verses.text: Seek not money, nor splendor of family, nor greatness of country; all these things are superfluous; but piety of soul, gentleness, the true understanding, the fear of God, if thou wishest thy darling to live with pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:324
verses.text: For if thou seek a wealthier husband, not only wilt thou not benefit her, but thou wilt even harm her, by making her a slave instead of free.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:325
verses.text: For the pleasure she will reap from her golden trinkets will not be so great as will be the annoyance that comes of her slavery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:326
verses.text: I pray thee, seek not these things, but most of all, one of equal condition; if however this cannot be, rather one poorer than in better circumstances; if at least thou be desirous not of selling thy daughter to a master, but of giving her to a husband.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:327
verses.text: When thou hast thoroughly investigated the virtue of the man, and art about to give her to him, beseech Christ to be present: for He will not be ashamed to be so; it is the mystery of His presence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:328
verses.text: Yea rather beseech Him even in the first instance, to grant her such a suitor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:329
verses.text: Be not worse than the servant of Abraham, who, when sent on a pilgrimage so important, saw whither he ought to have recourse; wherefore also he obtained everything.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:330
verses.text: When thou art taking anxious pains, and seeking a husband for her, pray; say unto God, "whomsoever Thou wilt do Thou provide:" into His hands commit the matter; and He, honored in this way by thee, will requite thee with honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:331
verses.text: Two things indeed it is necessary to do; to commit the thing into His hands, and to seek such an orderly person as He Himself approves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:332
verses.text: When then thou makest a marriage, go not round from house to house borrowing mirrors and dresses; for the matter is not one of display, nor dost thou lead thy daughter to a pageant; but decking out thine house with what is in it, invite thy neighbors, and friends, and kindred.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:333
verses.text: As many as thou knowest to be of a good character, those invite, and bid them be content with what there is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:334
verses.text: Let no one from the orchestra be present, for such expense is superfluous, and unbecoming.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:335
verses.text: Before all the rest, invite Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:336
verses.text: Knowest thou whereby thou wilt invite Him? Whosoever, saith He, "hath done it to one of these least, hath done it to Me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:337
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:338
verses.text: xxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:339
verses.text: ) And think it not an annoying thing to invite the poor for Christ's sake; to invite harlots is an annoyance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:340
verses.text: For to invite the poor is a means of wealth, the other of ruin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:341
verses.text: Adorn the bride not with these ornaments that are made of gold, but with gentleness and modesty, and the customary robes; in place of all golden ornament and braiding, arraying her in blushes, and shamefacedness, and the not desiring such things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:342
verses.text: Let there be no uproar, no confusion; let the bridegroom be called, let him receive the virgin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:343
verses.text: The dinners and suppers, let them not be full of drunkenness, but of abundance and pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:344
verses.text: See how many good things will result, whenever we see such marriages as those; but from the marriages that are now celebrated, (if at least one ought to call them marriages and not pageants,) how many are the evils! The banquet hall is no sooner broken up, than straightway comes care and fear, lest aught that is borrowed should have been lost, and there succeeds to the pleasure melancholy intolerable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:345
verses.text: But this distress belongs to the mother-in-law,—nay, rather not even is the bride herself free; all that follows at least belongs to the bride herself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:346
verses.text: For to see all broken up, is a ground for sadness, to see the house desolate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:347
verses.text: There is Christ, here is Satan; there is cheerfulness, here anxious care; there pleasure, here pain; there expense, here nothing of the kind; there indecency, here modesty; there envy, here no envy; there drunkenness, here soberness, here health, here temperance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On Colossians 13:348
verses.text: Bearing in mind all these things, let us stay the evil at this point, that we may please God, and be counted worthy to obtain the good things promised to them that love Him, through the grace and love toward man of our Lord Jesus Christ, with whom, to the Father, together with the Holy Ghost, be glory, power, honor, now and for ever, and world without end, Amen.
